page.title: 11Buildings
page.content: The majority of the buildings in the area are agricultural, farm houses, barns, outbuildings and one granary, dating originally from l7th and l8th centuries but with various alterations and additions. They are generally brick built with tiles roofs, but some cob walls remain. A few traditional cob and thatch cottages survive, one noticeably at Chapel Cross. Culeaze Farmhouse is an attractive, sizeable dwelling, dating from l7l5, and is now a mixture of cob and brick with a slate roof. Some more recently built houses, occupied mainly by retired persons, and some modern bungalows are grouped near the Golf Club, with its modern Club House, close to small industries and in an isolated area down a rough track. Bere Lodge, Hyde, is an unusual octagonal dwelling on the edge of Wareham Forest.
